Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: REU/RET Physics Site at the University of Oklahoma
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Oklahoma Norman provides eight undergraduate students each summer the opportunity to participate in research on topics in astrophysics, atomic, molecular and optical physics, condensed matter physics and high energy physics. In addition to participating in research with an experienced mentor, the REU students will engage in activities such as seminars and lectures. Students will give two oral presentations on the research, one after two weeks and a final twenty-minute talk.

This project includes a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) site, where each summer two high school teachers from nearby school districts participate in a research project. The teachers will develop and build small scale experiments that can be transported or replicated in the high school classroom.

This REU/RET site will have a number of broader impacts. The site has a strong plan to recruit undergraduate students from institutions offering little or no research opportunities and from groups underrepresented in physics. The site has a strong evaluation plan which is designed to give feedback and to improve the project on an on-going basis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many physics teachers in Oklahoma and across the United States often do not have the resources and time to develop meaningful curriculum on interesting physics topics. Having Oklahoma high school teachers work one-on-one with college professors during the summers allows the teachers to research interesting physics topics. During their research, the teachers also develop physics curriculum that can be used by all high school teachers across the United States. Two Oklahoma high school teachers worked on finalizing a quantum mechanics curriculum which was design to teach high school students introductory quantum mechanics. The curriculum includes both hands-on activities as well as tutorials. Kits were developed to allow students hands on demonstrations on many of the principles of quantum mechanics. The curriculum is available for download from the OU physics web site and the kits are available for Oklahoma high school teachers for use in their class rooms. A third Oklahoma high school teachers was involved in developing curriculum on spectroscopy. The students will learn how to analyze light which will allow them to understand how we study stars and other astronomical objects. By providing access to high quality science material, the students will gain a better understanding of physics and astronomy which will increase their scientific literacy and will hopefully encourage students to pursue careers in STEM.
